article.title: Impossibility of dimension reduction in the nuclear norm

multiple_choice_question.text:
**Formula (2):**  
lim (n→∞) (log k_α(X) / log n) = 0

**What does this formula define?**
choices: The Lipschitz distortion of a metric space.
The condition for a Banach space to admit metric dimension reduction.
The Markov 2-convexity constant of a metric space.
The Hausdorff distance between two subsets of a metric space.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 1:**\n\n**Which statement accurately describes the graphs depicted in Figure 1?**
choices: The figure shows two diamond graphs, D3 (left) and D4 (right).
The figure shows a diamond graph, D3 (right), and a Laakso graph, L3 (left).
Both graphs are constructed iteratively by replacing edges with paths of length 3.
These graphs are used to demonstrate the concept of Hausdorff distance.

multiple_choice_question.text:
**Formula (6):**

∑_(k=1)^∞ ∑_(t∈Z) (1/2^(2k)) * E[d_m (f(x_t^(t-2^k)), f(x_t))^2] ≤ Π^2 ∑_(t∈Z) E[d_m (f(x_t), f(x_(t-1)))^2]

**What does this formula represent?**
choices: The definition of Lipschitz quotient between two metric spaces.
The definition of the Markov 2-convexity constant of a metric space (M, d_m).
The relationship between the minimal distance and Hausdorff distance of two subsets.
The triangle inequality for Schatten-von Neumann norms.
The triangle inequality for Schatten-von Neumann norms.
The Hölder inequality for Schatten-von Neumann norms.
The definition of the Schatten-von Neumann trace class.
